subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: I speak a variety of American Southern English.  I grew up in rural South Carolina (in the Pee Dee region, for those to whom it would help).  It s not quite
messageBody:
I speak a variety of American Southern English.  I grew up in rural South Carolina (in the Pee Dee region, for those to whom it would help).  It's not quite the same, but I know people who actually pronounce the "l" in salmon as well.

Ron Cameron

John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
Ron Cameron scripsit:

> Speak for yourself. In my dialect the "l" in palm, psalm, calm, balm, etc., is pronounced. :-)

Hmm. What dialect do you speak?

> With all these complexities regarding QS, it's a miracle we all ever learn to communicate with each other in the first place!

Orthodox has its advantages.

--
What asininity could I have uttered John Cowan <cowan@...>
that they applaud me thus? http://www.ccil. org/~cowan
--Phocion, Greek orator

Be a better pen pal. Text or chat with friends inside Yahoo! Mail. See how.

I speak a variety of American Southern English.  I grew up in rural South Carolina (in the Pee Dee region, for those to whom it would help).  It's not quite the same, but I know people who actually pronounce the "l" in salmon as well.

Ron Cameron
